content: LankaTel was founded in 1998 in Colombo, Sri Lanka. The company started operations with a vision to bring affordable, reliable telecommunications services to every Sri Lankan household. Beginning with modest resources, LankaTel has grown to become one of Sri Lanka's leading telecommunications providers.

LankaTel launched its first dial-up internet service in November 1998, offering speeds of up to 56 kbps. By 2000, the company had expanded to serve customers across Colombo and Gampaha districts. In 2001, LankaTel became the first private ISP in Sri Lanka to lay its own fiber optic cables, connecting Colombo to Kandy.

In March 2003, LankaTel launched Sri Lanka's first commercially available ADSL broadband service under the brand 'LankaTel Broadband'. Initial speeds of 512 kbps were revolutionary for the local market. In 2007, LankaTel introduced the 'Gama' (Village) initiative to bring internet connectivity to rural Sri Lanka.

LankaTel acquired mobile spectrum licenses in 2008 and launched mobile data services in 2009 under the brand 'LankaTel Mobile'. The company built out its 3G network, covering all major cities by 2010. In 2011, LankaTel introduced Sri Lanka's first unlimited mobile data plan 'Anantha' (Unlimited).

LankaTel launched its 4G LTE network in Colombo in December 2013, becoming one of the first operators in Sri Lanka to offer 4G services. The network expanded rapidly, reaching extensive population coverage by 2016. The 'Digital Lanka' initiative launched in 2017 aimed to provide free Wi-Fi in public locations across the country.

In 2018, LankaTel launched its Fiber to the Home (FTTH) project to bring gigabit speeds to urban Sri Lanka. Fiber coverage expanded to homes across Colombo, Gampaha, and Kandy districts. During the COVID-19 pandemic, LankaTel supported remote workers with work-from-home packages and accelerated network deployment.

LankaTel launched commercial 5G services in 2021 in select areas of Colombo, becoming one of the first operators in Sri Lanka to offer 5G to consumers. The company introduced IoT solutions for smart cities and agriculture under the 'LankaTel Smart' brand. LankaTel continues to expand its services nationwide with plans for extensive 5G coverage.

LankaTel has received numerous industry awards including: 'Best ISP Sri Lanka' - World Communication Awards (multiple years), 'Most Innovative Telecom Company' - South Asian Telecom Summit, 'Best Employer in Technology Sector' - Great Place to Work Sri Lanka, 'Corporate Social Responsibility Excellence Award' - Ceylon Chamber of Commerce, 'Green Telecom Initiative Award' - ITU Asia Pacific.

Key milestones in LankaTel's journey: 1998 - Company founded, 1998 - First dial-up service launched, 2001 - First private fiber network in Sri Lanka, 2003 - ADSL broadband launched, 2009 - Mobile services launched, 2011 - First unlimited data plan in Sri Lanka, 2013 - 4G LTE launched, 2018 - FTTH project launched, 2021 - 5G commercial launch.

LankaTel was founded on the belief that access to information and communication is a fundamental right. The company's mission has always been to connect every Sri Lankan, from urban centers to remote villages, with affordable, reliable telecommunications services. LankaTel aims to bridge the digital divide and empower every citizen to participate in the global digital economy.

LankaTel's first Chief Executive Officer was appointed in 1998, bringing extensive telecommunications experience from international markets. The founding leadership team consisted of five executives with backgrounds in technology, finance, and operations. Early leadership focused on building infrastructure and establishing LankaTel as a reliable service provider. The company's leadership philosophy emphasized innovation, customer service, and sustainable growth.

LankaTel was initially funded through a combination of private equity investment and bank loans totaling LKR 500 million. The founding investors included local business leaders and international telecommunications investors. Initial capital was allocated primarily to network infrastructure, customer service facilities, and technology acquisition. By 2000, the company had secured additional funding of LKR 1.2 billion for network expansion.

LankaTel signed its first 100 customers within three months of launch in 1998. By the end of 1999, the company had reached 1,000 customers, primarily in Colombo. The 10,000 customer milestone was achieved in 2002, marking significant growth in the dial-up internet market. Customer acquisition accelerated with the launch of ADSL services in 2003.

In 2000, LankaTel established its first major international partnership with a global telecommunications equipment manufacturer. This partnership enabled access to cutting-edge technology and best practices. The collaboration focused on network infrastructure development and technical training for LankaTel engineers. This partnership model became a cornerstone of LankaTel's technology advancement strategy.

LankaTel's 'Gama' (Village) initiative launched in 2007 was a landmark program to bring internet connectivity to rural Sri Lanka. The initiative established internet kiosks in 50 villages across the country, providing free or low-cost internet access to rural communities. By 2010, the program had expanded to 200 villages, reaching over 100,000 rural residents. The initiative won recognition from the United Nations for bridging the digital divide.

LankaTel established its first data center in Colombo in 2005, providing hosting and cloud services to businesses. The facility featured state-of-the-art infrastructure with redundant power, cooling systems, and security measures. The data center became a critical component of LankaTel's enterprise services. Expansion to a second data center in Kandy occurred in 2012 to provide disaster recovery capabilities.

Following the 2009 mobile service launch, LankaTel rapidly expanded its mobile network coverage. By 2010, 3G coverage reached all major cities including Colombo, Kandy, Galle, Jaffna, and Negombo. The company invested LKR 5 billion in mobile infrastructure between 2009-2012. Rural mobile coverage expansion began in 2011, bringing mobile connectivity to previously underserved areas.

In 2010, LankaTel explored the possibility of an Initial Public Offering (IPO) on the Colombo Stock Exchange. The company engaged financial advisors and conducted market analysis. However, the IPO was postponed to focus on network expansion and service improvements. The company remains privately held with strategic investors, maintaining flexibility for rapid growth and innovation.

LankaTel established its Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) department in 2006, formalizing the company's commitment to social development. Early CSR initiatives included computer literacy programs in schools, free internet access for libraries, and support for educational institutions. The 'LankaTel Foundation' was established in 2010 to coordinate all CSR activities. Annual CSR investment has grown from LKR 50 million in 2006 to over LKR 500 million in recent years.

LankaTel received its first international recognition in 2004 when it won the 'Best Emerging ISP' award at the World Communication Awards in London. This recognition validated the company's innovative approach and rapid growth. The award was presented for LankaTel's successful ADSL rollout and rural connectivity initiatives. This marked the beginning of LankaTel's recognition on the global telecommunications stage.

LankaTel has invested over LKR 50 billion in network infrastructure since 1998. Major investment phases included: LKR 2 billion (1998-2002) for initial fiber network, LKR 8 billion (2003-2007) for ADSL expansion, LKR 15 billion (2008-2012) for mobile network, LKR 12 billion (2013-2017) for 4G LTE, LKR 10 billion (2018-2020) for FTTH, and LKR 8 billion (2021-present) for 5G deployment. These investments have created one of Sri Lanka's most extensive telecommunications networks.

In 2003, LankaTel became a consortium member of the South East Asia-Middle East-Western Europe (SEA-ME-WE) submarine cable system. This connection provided LankaTel with direct international bandwidth, reducing dependency on satellite links. The submarine cable connection significantly improved international connectivity speeds and reliability. LankaTel later joined additional submarine cable systems to ensure redundancy and capacity.

LankaTel started with 25 employees in 1998, growing to 150 employees by 2002. The company reached 500 employees in 2008 with the mobile service launch. By 2015, LankaTel employed over 1,200 people across various departments. Current employee count exceeds 2,000, making LankaTel one of the largest private sector employers in Sri Lanka's technology sector. The company has maintained a strong focus on employee development and career growth.

LankaTel opened its first customer service center in Colombo Fort in 1999, providing in-person support for customers. The service center handled account inquiries, bill payments, and technical support. By 2005, LankaTel had established service centers in Kandy, Galle, and Negombo. Today, LankaTel operates over 50 service centers across Sri Lanka, providing convenient access to customer services in all major cities and towns.

LankaTel established its Technology Innovation Lab in 2012 to research and develop new telecommunications solutions. The lab focuses on 5G technologies, IoT applications, artificial intelligence in network management, and next-generation services. Research partnerships with universities and international technology companies have been established. The lab has filed several patents and contributed to industry standards development.

LankaTel signed its first major enterprise customer in 2000, a leading bank requiring dedicated internet connectivity. This marked LankaTel's entry into the business services market. The enterprise division was formally established in 2002 to serve corporate customers. Today, LankaTel serves over 5,000 enterprise customers including banks, government institutions, and multinational corporations.

LankaTel implemented comprehensive network redundancy measures starting in 2004 to ensure service reliability. This included backup power systems, redundant network paths, and disaster recovery facilities. The company achieved 99.9% network uptime by 2008, setting industry standards in Sri Lanka. Network reliability improvements have been continuous, with current uptime exceeding 99.95%. These measures ensure uninterrupted service for customers.

LankaTel launched its first mobile application 'MyLankaTel' in 2014, allowing customers to manage accounts, pay bills, and monitor usage from smartphones. The app was initially available for Android devices, with iOS version launched in 2015. The app has been continuously updated with new features and improvements. Today, MyLankaTel has over 2 million active users and is one of the most downloaded apps in Sri Lanka.

In 2015, LankaTel explored opportunities for international expansion, particularly in South Asian markets. Market research was conducted in Bangladesh, Nepal, and Maldives. However, the company decided to focus on strengthening its position in Sri Lanka before international expansion. The international expansion strategy remains under consideration for future growth phases.

LankaTel launched its Green Energy Initiative in 2010, committing to reduce carbon footprint and environmental impact. The company installed solar panels at major facilities, reducing grid electricity consumption by 30%. Energy-efficient equipment and practices were implemented across operations. LankaTel achieved carbon-neutral status for its data centers in 2018. The initiative has won multiple environmental awards.

LankaTel connected its first Fiber to the Home (FTTH) customer in Colombo in 2018, marking a new era of high-speed internet. The customer received gigabit-speed internet, a first for residential customers in Sri Lanka. FTTH service quickly gained popularity, with 10,000 fiber customers by end of 2019. The fiber network has become LankaTel's flagship service, offering the fastest residential internet speeds in the country.

LankaTel established partnerships with major universities in 2009, providing discounted internet services and free Wi-Fi on campuses. Partnerships include University of Colombo, University of Peradeniya, SLIIT, and NSBM. The company also sponsors technology labs and provides internship opportunities for students. These partnerships support LankaTel's commitment to education and technology development in Sri Lanka.

LankaTel reached significant customer milestones: 10,000 customers (2002), 50,000 customers (2006), 100,000 customers (2009), 500,000 customers (2013), 1 million customers (2016), 2 million customers (2019), and 3 million customers (2022). Each milestone represented growth in different service categories - dial-up, ADSL, mobile, and fiber. The company's customer base continues to grow across all service segments.

LankaTel conducted its first 5G network test in 2020, achieving speeds exceeding 1 Gbps in controlled conditions. The test was conducted in partnership with international technology vendors. Successful testing led to commercial 5G launch in 2021. 5G testing continues to expand coverage and improve performance. LankaTel aims to provide 5G coverage to all major urban areas by 2025.

LankaTel established comprehensive disaster recovery and business continuity plans following the 2004 tsunami. The company invested in redundant infrastructure, backup systems, and emergency response procedures. These measures were tested during natural disasters and proved effective in maintaining service continuity. LankaTel's disaster recovery capabilities have been recognized as industry-leading in Sri Lanka.

LankaTel established its first international roaming partnership in 2010, enabling customers to use mobile services abroad. Initial partnerships covered India, Singapore, and UAE. The roaming network has expanded to over 200 countries and territories. LankaTel offers competitive roaming rates and special roaming packages for frequent travelers. International roaming has become a key service for business and leisure travelers.

LankaTel's network coverage has expanded from Colombo in 1998 to nationwide coverage today. Coverage milestones: Colombo and Gampaha (1998-2000), Kandy and Galle (2001-2003), All major cities (2004-2008), 80% population coverage (2009-2012), 90% population coverage (2013-2017), 95% population coverage (2018-present). The company continues to invest in expanding coverage to remote areas, aiming for near-universal coverage.

LankaTel launched its first prepaid data package in 2010, offering 1GB for LKR 99 with 7-day validity. This marked a shift from time-based to data-based pricing. The package was popular and led to the introduction of various data packages. Today, LankaTel offers data packages ranging from 500MB to unlimited data, catering to diverse customer needs. Data packages have become the primary revenue driver for mobile services.

LankaTel achieved ISO 9001:2000 quality management certification in 2005, demonstrating commitment to quality standards. The company later achieved ISO 27001 for information security (2012) and ISO 14001 for environmental management (2014). These certifications validate LankaTel's commitment to quality, security, and environmental responsibility. Regular audits ensure continued compliance with international standards.

LankaTel launched its first television commercial in 2003, promoting ADSL broadband services. The commercial featured local actors and highlighted the benefits of high-speed internet. Marketing campaigns have evolved over the years, emphasizing different services and customer benefits. LankaTel's advertising has won several marketing awards for creativity and effectiveness. The company continues to invest in brand building and customer awareness.

LankaTel's network speeds have evolved dramatically: 56 kbps dial-up (1998), 512 kbps ADSL (2003), 2 Mbps ADSL (2005), 8 Mbps ADSL (2008), 3G mobile up to 21 Mbps (2009), 4G LTE up to 150 Mbps (2013), Fiber up to 1 Gbps (2018), 5G up to 2 Gbps (2021). Each speed improvement has enabled new applications and services. LankaTel continues to invest in network upgrades to provide faster speeds.

LankaTel established its first call center in 2001 to provide 24/7 customer support via phone. Initially staffed by 20 agents, the call center handled customer inquiries, technical support, and billing questions. The call center has grown to over 500 agents across multiple locations. Modern call centers use advanced technology including AI-powered chatbots and automated systems to enhance customer service efficiency.

LankaTel published its first annual report in 1999, documenting the company's first full year of operations. The report highlighted customer growth, network expansion, and financial performance. Annual reports have become comprehensive documents covering all aspects of LankaTel's operations. The reports are published in Sinhala, Tamil, and English to reach all stakeholders. Annual reports are available online and in print.

LankaTel's first major sponsorship was the LankaTel Cricket Cup in 2002, supporting local cricket development. The company has since sponsored various sports, cultural, and educational events. Major sponsorships include national cricket team support, music festivals, technology conferences, and educational programs. Sponsorships align with LankaTel's brand values and community engagement objectives.

LankaTel experienced its first significant cybersecurity incident in 2007, which was successfully contained and resolved. The incident led to enhanced cybersecurity measures and the establishment of a dedicated security team. LankaTel now employs advanced security technologies and practices to protect customer data and network infrastructure. The company has maintained an excellent security record since implementing comprehensive security measures.

LankaTel completed its first national fiber backbone in 2006, connecting major cities with high-capacity fiber links. The backbone provided the foundation for high-speed services across the country. The network has been continuously upgraded and expanded. Today, LankaTel operates one of the most extensive fiber networks in Sri Lanka, spanning over 10,000 kilometers of fiber cable.

LankaTel deployed its first Internet of Things (IoT) solution in 2019, implementing smart water meters for a municipal water supply project. This marked LankaTel's entry into the IoT market. The company has since deployed IoT solutions for agriculture, smart cities, and industrial applications. LankaTel Smart IoT platform was launched in 2021 to provide comprehensive IoT services for businesses and government.

LankaTel launched its first cloud computing service 'LankaTel Cloud' in 2016, offering Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) to businesses. The service provided virtual servers, storage, and networking capabilities. Cloud services have expanded to include Software as a Service (SaaS) and Platform as a Service (PaaS) offerings. LankaTel Cloud serves over 1,000 business customers, providing scalable and cost-effective cloud solutions.

LankaTel participated in its first international telecommunications conference in 2005, attending the ITU World Telecommunication Development Conference. Company representatives presented papers on rural connectivity and broadband deployment. International conference participation has become regular, with LankaTel sharing expertise and learning from global best practices. The company has hosted several regional telecommunications conferences in Sri Lanka.

LankaTel celebrated its 25th anniversary in 2023 with a series of events and initiatives. The celebration included customer appreciation programs, employee recognition events, and community service activities. Special anniversary packages and promotions were offered to customers. The company reflected on its journey from a small startup to a leading telecommunications provider, while looking forward to future innovations and growth.

LankaTel completed its first major network upgrade in 2002, increasing capacity and improving reliability. The upgrade involved replacing older equipment with modern technology and expanding network capacity by 300%. This upgrade enabled the company to support more customers and prepare for ADSL service launch. Network upgrades have been continuous, with major upgrades every 3-5 years to incorporate latest technologies.

LankaTel conducted its first comprehensive customer satisfaction survey in 2004, gathering feedback from over 5,000 customers. The survey revealed areas for improvement and helped shape customer service initiatives. Regular customer satisfaction surveys have become standard practice, conducted quarterly. Customer satisfaction scores have improved consistently, with current scores exceeding 85% satisfaction rate. Feedback drives continuous service improvements.

LankaTel established its employee training program in 2000, focusing on technical skills and customer service. The program has evolved to include leadership development, technology certifications, and soft skills training. LankaTel partners with international training providers and universities for advanced programs. The company invests over LKR 100 million annually in employee training and development. Training programs have contributed to high employee retention and service quality.

LankaTel signed its first major partnership with the Sri Lankan government in 2008, providing connectivity for e-government initiatives. The partnership involved connecting government offices and providing internet services for citizen services. This partnership expanded over the years, with LankaTel supporting various government digitalization projects. Government partnerships have been important for LankaTel's growth and social impact.

LankaTel made its first international bandwidth purchase in 2001, securing 155 Mbps capacity on the SEA-ME-WE submarine cable. This capacity was shared among early customers and enabled international connectivity. International bandwidth capacity has grown exponentially, with current capacity exceeding 100 Gbps. LankaTel maintains multiple international connectivity paths for redundancy and reliability.

LankaTel established its Network Operations Center (NOC) in 2003 to monitor network performance 24/7. The NOC uses advanced monitoring tools to detect and resolve network issues proactively. The center has grown to monitor all network elements including fiber, mobile, and data center infrastructure. The NOC ensures high network availability and quick response to any issues. Modern NOC uses AI and machine learning for predictive maintenance.

LankaTel launched its customer loyalty program in 2012, rewarding long-term customers with points, discounts, and exclusive offers. The program has evolved to include tiered benefits (Silver, Gold, Platinum) based on customer tenure and spending. Loyalty program members receive priority support, special packages, and anniversary rewards. The program has over 500,000 active members and has contributed to high customer retention rates.

LankaTel opened its first rural internet kiosk in 2007 in a village in the Central Province. The kiosk provided free internet access to villagers and training on computer and internet usage. This was part of the 'Gama' initiative to bridge the digital divide. The kiosk model was replicated in 200 villages across Sri Lanka. Rural kiosks have enabled thousands of rural residents to access internet and digital services for the first time.

LankaTel launched 'LankaTel Pay' mobile money service in 2017, allowing customers to make payments, transfer money, and pay bills using mobile phones. The service was initially available to LankaTel customers and later expanded to all mobile users. LankaTel Pay has grown to over 1 million registered users and processes millions of transactions monthly. The service has enabled financial inclusion for many Sri Lankans.

LankaTel received the 'Most Innovative Telecom Company' award at the South Asian Telecom Summit in 2015. The award recognized LankaTel's innovative services including unlimited data plans, fiber-to-home deployment, and rural connectivity initiatives. This was the first major innovation award for the company. LankaTel has since received multiple innovation awards, establishing its reputation as an innovative telecommunications provider.
